title: Deploy Audit service on OpenShift
content:
This section gives the steps required to install the Audit service.

Prepare the certificates

You need to copy the database and IDM certificates (base64 encoded) in the same folder where you have downloaded the Audit Helm chart (for example, audit-2x.x). 

Generate vault secrets

A secret is an object that has sensitive data such as a password, a token, or a key.

Use the gen_secrets.sh script to create secrets. This script creates a YAML file that contains all the Audit secrets. You must pass this YAML file in the command line during Audit installation. 

To generate vault secrets for the Audit charts, perform the following steps on the bastion node:

  1. Run the following command:

    $CDF_HOME/scripts/gen_secrets.sh -n <Audit Namespace> -c <Audit Chart File> -o <Secrets YAML File>

    where,
    <Audit Namespace> is the unique namespace of the Audit deployment.
    <Audit Chart File> is the tar file containing the Audit installation charts (audit-<version>.tgz)
    <Secrets YAML File> is the YAML file that stores the Audit secrets. Specify the file name (for example, audit-secrets.yaml), and then the script will generate this YAML file after you run the script. You will need to use this file when you run the command to install Audit later.

    For example:

    /root/cdf/scripts/gen_secrets.sh -n auditns -c audit-<version>.tgz -o audit-secrets.yaml

  2. The vault secret utility prompts you for the following passwords: audit_db_pass_key, idm_transport_user_pass_key, and idm_super_user_pass_key. IdM must have the IdM transport user and the super user (suite admin). If you want to use new users, give the transport user and super user permissions to these users.

The following table describes the vault secret keys:

Key Required Description
audit_db_pass_key Yes Audit database password.
idm_transport_user_pass_key Yes

IdM transport user password.
idm_super_user_pass_key Yes IdM super user password. For example, if you use suite admin as the super user, then give the password of the suite admin.

IdM transport user password

To retrieve the idmTransportUser password from the IdM container, run the following command:

kubectl exec <IDM POD> -n itsma-qcml0 -c idm -- get_secret idm_transport_user_password_secret_key

For example,

kubectl exec idm-7b87f8bbfc-bwswl -n itsma-qcml0 -c idm -- get_secret idm_transport_user_password_secret_key

Install the service

To complete the deployment, you will need to install the Audit service using Helm.

Run the following command:

$helm install <Audit Release Name> <Audit Service Chart> -n <Audit Namespace> -f values.yaml -f <Secrets YAML File> --set-file "caCertificates.cert_one\.crt"=/path/to/cert_one.crt --set-file "caCertificates.cert_two\.crt"=/path/to/cert_two.crt --set-file "caCertificates.cert_three\.crt"=/path/to/cert_three.crt

where,
<Audit Release Name> is the unique release name that you need to specify for the Audit deployment. You need to use the same release name as specified here when you upgrade Audit in the future.
<Audit Service Chart> is the tar file containing the Audit installation charts.
<Audit Namespace> is the unique namespace you created for the Audit service.
<Values YAML File> is your values.yaml file with properties configured for the Audit deployment.
<Secrets YAML File> is the YAML file that stores the Audit secrets. Specify the file name (for example, audit-secrets.yaml).
You can pass certificates using the --set-file option. In the following example, you can see the suite, database, and Audit service engine certificates.

For example:

$helm install audit audit-<version>.tgz -n auditns -f values.yaml -f audit-secrets.yaml --set-file "caCertificates.RE_ca_idmcrt"=./RE_ca_idm.crt --set-file "caCertificates.RE_ca_dbcrt"=./RE_ca_db.crt --set-file "caCertificates.ase.crt"=./ase.crt

Verify the installation

To verify if you have installed the Audit service successfully, do the following:

  1. Log in to the bastion node.

  2. Run the following command to make sure that all pods are ready:

    kubectl get pod -n <Audit Namespace> |grep -v 1/1|grep -v 2/2|grep -v 3/3|grep -v 4/4|grep -v Completed

    where,

    <Audit Namespace> is the namespace where you have deployed the Audit Helm chart.

    This command returns a list of abnormal pods. When it returns no results, all pods are ready.

(Optional) Enable Audit menu for existing active tenants

If there are active tenants in the system before installing Audit, you can enable the Audit menu in the agent interface for each of these tenants. To do so, you should run the EnableAuditMegaMenu.bin, which is part of the Audit Helm package.

Enable Audit menu for all active tenants

To enable the Audit menu for all the active tenants, follow these steps:

  1. Navigate to the audit install directory audit-<version> that you created when downloading the Audit Helm chart. For example:

    cd <audit_install-dir>/audit-2x.x

  2. Run the following command to enable Audit:

    ./EnableAuditMegaMenu.bin -f <Service Management Hostname> -p <Service Management Port> -a <Audit Service URL>

    For example:

    ./EnableAuditMegaMenu.bin -f smax.example.com -p 443 -a https://audit.example.com:443
  3. When prompted for a password, give the password for the seeded integration user.

Enable Audit menu for a specific active tenant

To enable the Audit menu for a specific active tenant, follow these steps:

  1. Navigate to the audit install directory audit-<version> that you created when downloading the Audit Helm chart. For example:

    cd <audit_install-dir>/audit-2x.x

  2. Run the following command to enable Audit:

    ./EnableAuditMegaMenu.bin -f <Service Management hostname> -p <Service Management port> -a <Audit Service URL> -t <Tenant ID>

    For example:

    ./EnableAuditMegaMenu.bin -f smax.example.com -p 443 -a https://audit.example.com:443 -t 123456

  3. When prompted for a password, give the password of the seeded integration user.

  • To obtain the suite CA certificate, see Get the suite CA certificate.
